docs.title: Ticket Numbers (Food Courts / Restaurants)
docs.text:
When you order and get a ticket number, listen for your number + "ban" (番):

Number Japanese Say it 100 百 hyaku 101 百一 hyaku-ichi 102 百二 hyaku-ni 103 百三 hyaku-san 104 百四 hyaku-yon 105 百五 hyaku-go 106 百六 hyaku-roku 107 百七 hyaku-nana 108 百八 hyaku-hachi 109 百九 hyaku-kyū 110 百十 hyaku-jū 111 百十一 hyaku-jū-ichi 112 百十二 hyaku-jū-ni

Pattern: hyaku (100) + jū (10s) + ones digit + "ban!"

Basic numbers 1-10 refresher:

# Japanese 1 ichi 2 ni 3 san 4 yon 5 go 6 roku 7 nana 8 hachi 9 kyū 10 jū

Useful phrases: - Show your ticket and say: "Kore desu" (This is me!) - Didn't hear? "Mou ichido onegaishimasu" (One more time please)

docs.title: ♨️ Jozankei Onsen (On the way home)
docs.text:
🏆 Top Pick: Hoheikyo Onsen - ¥1,300 adults / ¥600 kids - HUGE outdoor rotenburo (holds 200 people!) with stunning mountain views - Tattoo-friendly ✓ - Day-trip only facility — no hotel guests, so it's all about the baths - Free shuttle from Jozankei town - Indoor pool is carved sandstone, outdoor is the showstopper - 📍 Google Maps

Good budget options: - Matsunoyu — ¥800, cheapest proper onsen - Yunohana Jozankeiden — ¥980, variety of different baths - Hatagoya Shoten — ¥980, adults only (13+)

What to know: - Bring your own towel or rent one (usually ¥200-300) - Wash thoroughly before entering baths - No swimwear — it's naked - Tattoos: Hoheikyo is explicitly OK; others may give you looks but rarely enforce - Most have coin lockers for valuables

Free foot baths if you just want a taste: Futami-no-ashiyu and Taro-no-yu

Location: Hoheikyo is about 10 mins past main Jozankei — worth the extra trip for that massive outdoor bath! 🧖‍♂️

docs.title: ASAHIDAKE
docs.text: Base: Court Hotel Asahikawa

docs.title: Quick Stats
docs.text:
• Size: TINY (1 ropeway, 4 groomed cat tracks)
  • Actual terrain: Massive unpatrolled backcountry zone
  • Annual snowfall: ~14m (estimated — no one really measures it!)
  • Vertical: 500m (ropeway accessed)
  • Top elevation: 1,600m (highest lift-access in Hokkaido)
  • Season: Mid-December to early May
  • Trail Map: View Map
  • Best for: Advanced/expert powder hunters who love tree skiing and backcountry
  • NOT for: Beginners, intermediates, or anyone who won't ride off-piste

docs.title: From Our Accommodation
docs.text:
Base: Court Hotel Asahikawa Distance: ~70km Travel time: ~70 minutes Route: Asahikawa → Route 39 → Route 213 (Asahidake Onsen) Google Maps: View route

Parking: - Large parking lot at ropeway base - ¥500/day for cars (8 bus spaces, 50 car spaces) - Free for ropeway users (check current policy)

Route notes: - Straightforward highway driving through Daisetsuzan region - Beautiful scenic route through national park - Road is well-maintained but expect winter conditions - Asahidake Onsen village is at top of road (small cluster of hotels + ropeway)

docs.title: ⚠️ THIS IS NOT A SKI RESORT — IT'S BACKCOUNTRY
docs.text: Critical: Asahidake is unpatrolled, uncontrolled backcountry with ropeway access - No ski patrol - No avalanche control - No marked runs (4 groomed cat tracks are just exit routes) - Trail maps have warnings: rescue off-piste at your own cost - MUST carry beacon, shovel, probe

docs.title: Off-Piste Policy
docs.text: ✅ ALLOWED — but you're on your own - Essentially the entire mountain is off-piste - Treat as backcountry: assess snow stability, plan routes, manage risks - Active volcano = heavy snow loads on warm ground = increased ava risk - Fumaroles (volcanic vents) in alpine zone can be hazardous

docs.title: In-Bounds Trees
docs.text: 🌲 Beautiful tree skiing - Well-spaced trees in lower 2/3 of ropeway zone - Pick any line you fancy once into the trees - Some zones require route-finding (creek crossings, terrain traps) - Snowboarder-friendly spacing BUT...

docs.title: ⚠️ SNOWBOARDER CHALLENGES
docs.text:
• Bottom third gets flat — exit via groomed cat tracks (can be tedious)
  • Many sidecountry lines don't run fall-line → shuffling/poling required
  • Creek crossing 2/3 down forces you back to groomed trails
  • Serious flat zones if you pick wrong line
  • Consider hiring a guide if you want to maximize terrain (minimize flat suffering)

docs.title: Hot Tips: Powder Stashes & Tree Runs
Powder Strategy
docs.text:
• Hit early AM — freshies disappear fast near ropeway top
  • Fan out wider — fresh tracks available at lunch if you're willing to hike a bit
  • Short hikes = big rewards — sidecountry has steeper pitches, less tracked
  • Alpine touring — endless terrain above ropeway (skin/snowshoe required)

docs.title: Best Zones (Ropeway Accessed)
docs.text:
TOP SECTION (Alpine & Upper Trees) - Reasonably open with short steep pitches - Some natural hits (rocks, small cliffs, mushrooms) - Gets tracked quickly but refills often with ~14m/year snowfall - Skier's left has nice steep bowls (short hike required)

MID SECTION (Trees) - Well-spaced pines and evergreens - Pick your line — all routes lead down - Best powder: Protected from wind, stays light and fluffy - Beautiful tree skiing for advanced riders

LOWER SECTION - Terrain flattens out - Creek crossing forces exit via groomed trails - Groundhog Day feeling (same exit runs repeatedly)

docs.title: Sidecountry (Short Hikes)
docs.text:
• Hike up/out from ropeway top for steeper pitches
  • Skier's left: Short hikes access nice bowls
  • Skier's right: Various lines but many flatten out or end at river (dead ends)
  • Route-finding essential — easy to end up in closed valleys requiring trudging

docs.title: Alpine Terrain (Skin/Snowshoe)
docs.text:
• Massive expanse above ropeway
  • Steep bowls, expert lines
  • Weather dependent: Visibility often poor, snow can be wind-scoured
  • Hazards: Fumaroles (stinky volcanic vents), cracks, poor visibility
  • Recommended: Hire a guide for alpine touring

docs.title: DON'T MISS
docs.text:
• Tree skiing — lower 2/3 of ropeway zone (the real goods!)
  • Short hike zones — sidecountry above ropeway top
  • Powder laps — anywhere in trees after fresh snow
  • Alpine bowls — if you're touring/have a guide

docs.title: SKIPPABLE
docs.text:
• Groomed cat tracks — boring! (Only use for exit)
  • Flat zones — unavoidable on exit, but not the point

docs.title: RECOVERY RUNS
docs.text:
• Groomed trails — mellow cat tracks for when you're tired
  • This is NOT a recovery mountain — go elsewhere for cruising

docs.title: LUNCH (Ropeway Building Only)
docs.text:
Cafeteria (Ropeway Base Building) - Inexpensive, basic ski cafeteria food - Noodles, curry rice, typical Japanese ski food - Nothing fancy but gets the job done - Pro tip: Pork buns from kiosk while waiting for ropeway!

Food Kiosk - Snacks, drinks, pork buns - Limited selection

THAT'S IT. No other on-mountain dining options.

docs.text:

  • Can visit hotel restaurants for lunch (walk down from ropeway)
  • Better food but costs time/skiing

docs.text:
Feb 5 = Regular Season (Nov 1 - May 31)

Pass Type Adult (Jr High+) Child (Elementary) Round-trip ¥2,800 ¥1,750 One-way ¥1,700 ¥1,100

docs.title: KEY NOTES
docs.text:
• Not a "lift pass" — it's a ropeway fare (like a cable car)
  • Ropeway runs every 20 minutes (every 10min on busy days)
  • Limited capacity = natural crowd control
  • Children under elementary age = FREE (one per adult)
  • No multi-day passes available
  • Group discounts available (15+ people): ¥2,500 adult round-trip

docs.title: ROPEWAY OPERATION
docs.text:
Feb 5 hours: 9:00am - 3:40pm (last down) - Hours vary by season (check daily status) - Winter: typically 9am-4pm - Closed mid-November to early December (maintenance) - Frequent wind closures — check morning status before driving

Website: https://asahidake.hokkaido.jp/en/

docs.title: ⚠️ WEATHER-DEPENDENT OPERATION
docs.text: BIGGEST ISSUE: Ropeway closes frequently due to high winds - Even moderate winds can shut it down - Check operation status morning-of (website has current conditions) - Backup plan essential — consider Kurodake (other side of mountain) or bail to another resort

docs.title: ❄️ WEATHER CAN BE BRUTAL
docs.text:
• Often poor visibility during peak winter
  • Temperatures can hit -27°C (we're not kidding!)
  • Heavy snowfall = whiteout conditions
  • Wind-scoured snow in alpine zone
  • BUT: This is when the powder is best!

docs.title: 🐌 LOW VERTICAL OUTPUT
docs.text:
• Only 500m per lap
  • Ropeway every 20min = ~10 runs/day max (without skinning)
  • Relatively leisurely day compared to lift-serviced resorts
  • This is backcountry pace — quality over quantity

docs.title: 🎿 WALK TO SKI
docs.text:
• Ropeway built for hikers, not skiers
  • Must walk uphill from top station before you can drop in
  • Annoying but minor

docs.title: 🏔️ ACTIVE VOLCANO
docs.text:
• Fumaroles emit steam and sulfurous gas (stinky!)
  • Some cracks/hazards in alpine zone
  • Generally safe but adds to backcountry hazards

docs.title: 🚫 NO AMENITIES
docs.text:
• No rental shop (bring your own gear or rent in Asahikawa)
  • No terrain park, no pipe
  • Tiny village (Asahidake Onsen) = very limited nightlife/restaurants
  • National park = minimal development

docs.title: 🏂 SNOWBOARDERS: MANAGE EXPECTATIONS
docs.text:
• Trees are great
  • Flat exits are tedious
  • Sidecountry has flat traps
  • Strong recommendation: Hire a guide to maximize good terrain and avoid flat suffering

docs.title: 🏂 Snowboarders: Real Talk
docs.text:
This mountain will test your patience on the flats, but reward you in the trees.

Pros: - Tree spacing is perfect for boards - Powder is world-class (dry, deep, cold) - Minimal crowds = fresh tracks - Natural hits everywhere

Cons: - Flat exit runs are tedious (will test your shuffle game) - Sidecountry has flat traps if you pick wrong line - Only 500m vertical per lap

Recommendation: - Hire a guide for first runs — they'll show you lines that minimize flats - Bring poles for shuffling - Manage expectations: this is backcountry, not a resort - If you hate flats, consider skipping and skiing Kamui instead

docs.title: 🎿 Advanced/Expert Skiers
docs.text: You will love this place. - Endless terrain if you're willing to skin - Tree skiing is sublime - Powder quality is as good as it gets - Hire a guide to unlock alpine zones

docs.title: 🎒 Gear Checklist
docs.text:
MUST BRING: - Beacon, shovel, probe (non-negotiable) - Fat powder skis/board - Warm layers (temps can hit -27°C) - Goggles (visibility often poor) - Poles for snowboarders (seriously!) - Water/snacks (limited on-mountain options)

Optional but recommended: - Splitboard or touring setup (if you want alpine zones) - Face mask/balaclava (it's COLD) - Extra batteries (cold kills them fast)

docs.title: 📅 Day Plan
docs.text: 07:30 — Depart Court Hotel Asahikawa 08:40 — Arrive Asahidake Ropeway, gear up 09:00 — First ropeway up 09:00-15:00 — Powder laps (expect ~8-10 runs) 15:00 — Last runs down 15:30 — Onsen soak at Asahidake Onsen hotel (optional) 16:30 — Depart for Asahikawa 17:40 — Back in Asahikawa 18:30 — Dinner at Tenkin

docs.text: If ropeway is closed due to wind: - Kurodake (Sounkyo side) — different ropeway, might be running - Kamui Ski Links — closer to Asahikawa, more lift-serviced - Bail to Asahikawa — rest day, explore sake brewery/zoo/city

docs.title: 🥶 Weather Reality Check
docs.text:
Feb 5 is PEAK WINTER. Expect: - Temperatures: -15°C to -25°C - Heavy snowfall possible - Whiteout conditions possible - Wind closures possible

This is HARDCORE skiing. Not a cruise day. Dress warm, stay safe, enjoy the best powder on Earth.

docs.title: FURANO SKI RESORT
docs.text: Base: Tomamu The Tower (Hoshino Resorts)

docs.title: Quick Stats
docs.text:
• Size: Large by Japanese standards (28 runs, 9 lifts + 2 gondolas)
  • Suitable for: 2-3 day visit (but great base for multi-area trips)
  • Annual snowfall: ~9m (less than coastal resorts, but drier/lighter)
  • Vertical: 839m (964m claimed but official is 839m)
  • Top elevation: 1,074m
  • Base elevation: 235m
  • Trail Map: Download PDF
  • Best for: Long groomed runs, tree skiing, sidecountry powder
  • Season: Late November to early May (Nov 29, 2025 - May 6, 2026)
  • Ikon Pass: Included from 2025-26 season (7 days on full pass)

docs.title: From Our Accommodation
docs.text:
Base: Tomamu The Tower (Hoshino Resorts, Tomamu) Distance: ~60km (39-41 miles) Travel time: ~55 minutes to 1 hour Route: Tomamu → Route 38 south → Route 237 northwest to Furano Google Maps: View route

Parking: - Free parking at resort base (both Furano Zone and Kitanomine Zone) - Multiple lots near ropeway/gondola stations - Well-marked, easy access

Route notes: - Straightforward highway driving - Route 237 is scenic through central Hokkaido farmland - Morning session plan: depart early, ski ~4 hours, drive to Asahikawa - Blue Pond detour: Add 40min if visiting Biei's famous Blue Pond (between Furano and Asahikawa)

docs.title: Off-Piste Policy
docs.text: ✅ ALLOWED (with discretion) — Huge upgrade! - Official ban no longer enforced (as of recent years) - Be discreet — don't duck ropes in front of patrol - Extensive sidecountry between Furano Zone and Kitanomine Zone - No pass-pulling if you're sensible about it

docs.title: Backcountry Access
docs.text:
• Gates available at top of Furano Zone
  • Requires proper avalanche gear (beacon, shovel, probe)
  • ⚠️ Not for us (no ava equipment/training planned)
  • Guided tours available to nearby Tokachidake backcountry

docs.title: In-Bounds Trees & Sidecountry
docs.text:
• Link Chair area = BEST ZONE (between two resort zones)
  • Skier's right (Furano Zone): Lines drop into drainage, return via goat-track
  • Skier's left: Sheltered gullies (but some exit away from resort — tricky)
  • Well-spaced trees, snowboarder-friendly
  • Sheltered aspect = powder holds up well after storms

docs.title: Premium Zone
docs.text:
• Steepest run (34° max, 23° average, 830m long)
  • Off-piste area, left ungroomed
  • ⚠️ Not always open (depends on snowfall/ava conditions)
  • Limited avalanche control

docs.title: Hot Tips: Powder Stashes & Tree Runs
Best Sidecountry Zones (Snowboarder-Friendly)
docs.text:
• Link Chair Area (PRIORITY #1)

    • Between Furano Zone and Kitanomine Zone
    • Accessible from top of Link Chair OR Furano Gondola
    • Multiple gullies funnel back to lifts (both zones)
    • Best feature: Lifts run in low wind (when other resorts shut down)
    • Can lap this zone all day on storm days
    • Short hikes above chair for bonus terrain (but ava-prone — be careful)

  • Skier's Right (Furano Zone)

    • Various sustained lines dropping into drainage
    • Return via goat-track along drainage (passes large concrete dam)
    • Longer hike out but quality powder
    • Less tracked than Link Chair area

  • Premium Zone (if open)

    • Steepest terrain, left ungroomed
    • Powder paradise after fresh snow
    • Check daily status (often closed)

docs.title: Powder Strategy
docs.text:
• ⚠️ Growing popularity (Ikon Pass + international visitors)
  • Hit sidecountry early AM — crowds stick to groomers first
  • Link Chair opens 9am (Furano Ropeway 8:30am)
  • Entries/exits can be obscure — takes time to track out
  • Storm day advantage: Furano's sheltered east aspect keeps lifts running when coastal resorts close (wind-hold)

docs.title: Terrain Notes
docs.text:
• On-piste: Long, fast groomed runs (former FIS World Cup courses)
  • Real gems: Sidecountry trees between zones
  • East-facing = rain shadow of Mt Furano-Nishi (less snow, more sun)
  • Better weather/visibility than coastal resorts like Niseko
  • Ungroomed runs left natural for powder

docs.title: DON'T MISS
docs.text:
• Link Chair sidecountry — prime zone, accessible in all conditions
  • Premium Zone — if open, this is the steepest/best
  • Long groomed cruisers — A2, A3, F1 (1.7-1.9km long)
  • Skier's right drainage lines — for committed powder hunters

docs.title: SKIPPABLE
docs.text:
• Beginner Zone — free area with snow escalators (families only)
  • Lower Kitanomine — mellow beginner terrain (good recovery runs though)

docs.title: RECOVERY RUNS
docs.text:
• F1 (Kitanomine) — 1,900m gentle cruise
  • A2 (Furano) — 1,750m intermediate, well-groomed
  • G1 (Kitanomine) — 1,080m beginner-friendly

docs.title: On-Mountain Food
docs.text: ⚠️ SEVERELY LIMITED — Powderhounds specifically warns about this!

docs.title: Furano Zone (Ropeway Base)
docs.text:

docs.title: ☀️ LOWER SNOWFALL (Pro/Con)
docs.text:
Con: 9m average vs 15m at coastal resorts (Niseko, Rusutsu) Pro: Drier, lighter powder + more bluebird days Con: Bad seasons are ROUGH (7-8m = lean pickings) Pro: East-facing sheltered aspect = great on storm days

Bottom line: Furano excels when others are closed (wind), but can lag in dry spells.

docs.title: 🌬️ STORM DAY HERO
docs.text:
• Sheltered east aspect = lifts run in high wind
  • When Niseko/Rusutsu are on wind-hold, Furano is lapping powder
  • Link Chair + Furano Gondola = low-wind-affected access

docs.title: 📈 GROWING CROWDS
docs.text:
• Ikon Pass = more international visitors
  • Powder gets tracked faster than it used to
  • Still MUCH less crowded than Niseko
  • Lift queues sometimes problematic (weekends/holidays)

docs.title: 🍜 LIMITED ON-MOUNTAIN FOOD
docs.text:
• "Severely lacking" per Powderhounds review
  • Only 4 restaurants for entire resort
  • Pack snacks or plan lunch in town

docs.title: 🏔️ BASE FOR MULTI-AREA TRIPS
docs.text:
• Great hub for day trips: Asahidake, Kamui, Tomamu, Sahoro, Tokachidake
  • Not ideal if locked into pre-paid packages (we have cars = perfect)

docs.title: 🏨 AVOID BIG HOTELS (Not Our Problem)
docs.text:
• Shin Furano Prince Hotel / Furano Prince Hotel = soulless, expensive, off to the side
  • Shuttle buses required, captive dining
  • We're not staying there — just FYI for future reference

docs.title: 🛁 Onsen (Tokachidake Area — ~40min from Furano)
docs.text:
• Fukiage Roten-no-yu 🌟

    • Distance: 40min drive from Furano (Mt Tokachidake)
    • Why visit: FREE, 24-hour, outdoor-only, in the woods
    • Type: Mixed gender (bring bathing suit if shy)
    • Vibe: Wild onsen under the stars, no artificial lighting
    • Time needed: 30-60 minutes
    • Perfect for: After-ski dip before driving to Asahikawa

  • Hakuginsou Hot Spring Centre

    • Distance: 40min from Furano (Fukiage Onsen area)
    • Why visit: 12 baths (male/female/mixed outdoor areas)
    • Features: Sauna, family-friendly mixed zones
    • Time needed: 1-2 hours

  • Ryounkaku Onsen

    • Distance: 40min from Furano
    • Why visit: 1,280m elevation, clifftop location, panoramic Tokachi volcano views
    • Features: Red-brown water, outdoor + indoor baths, sauna
    • Vibe: Dramatic high-altitude onsen experience
    • Time needed: 1-2 hours

docs.title: 🍺 Hop Kotan Brewing (Kamifurano)
docs.text: Distance: ~20min from Furano Ski Resort (in Kamifurano town) Why visit: Hokkaido craft brewery using local hops Beers: ORIGINALS series (100% Kamifurano hops), FREEDOMS (seasonal), Harvest Brews Taproom: Mountain lodge-style pub (formerly "Furano Brewery Yama no Doxon") Time needed: 1 hour (beer flight + snacks) Website: hopkotan.com

docs.title: 🌊 Biei Blue Pond (Shirogane)
docs.text: Distance: 40min from Furano, 25min from Asahikawa (ON ROUTE!) Why visit: Famous turquoise-blue pond (aluminum-rich water from Mt Tokachi dam) Nearby: Shirahige Falls (same area) Time needed: 15-20 minutes (quick photo stop) Best time: Winter = frozen with snow-covered trees (iconic photo) Note: Perfect detour on drive from Furano → Asahikawa

docs.title: 🍜 Furano Town Restaurants
docs.text: Distance: 3km from ski resort (5-10min drive) Options: - Authentic izakayas (local favorite: "The Bridge" cocktail bar) - Furano Delice (famous milk pudding) - Many small pensions and B&Bs with local charm Note: We're driving to Asahikawa for dinner, but good to know for future trips

docs.title: Snowboarders
docs.text:
• ✅ Link Chair sidecountry = board-friendly (well-spaced trees)
  • ✅ Long groomed runs = excellent for cruising
  • ⚠️ Some connector runs can be flat (stay on main routes)
  • ✅ Premium Zone (if open) = steep powder paradise

docs.title: Morning Session Strategy
docs.text:
• Goal: 4-hour powder hit, then drive to Asahikawa
  • Timeline:
  • 8:30am: First lifts (Furano Ropeway opens 8:30am)
  • 8:30-12:30pm: Lap Link Chair sidecountry + groomers
  • 12:30pm: Depart for Asahikawa
  • Optional: Blue Pond photo stop (+20min)
  • Optional: Fukiage onsen dip (+40min)
  • 2:30-3pm: Arrive Asahikawa, check-in Court Hotel

docs.title: Weather Considerations
docs.text:
• Check Premium Zone status morning-of (often closed)
  • If windy/stormy: PERFECT (Furano excels on storm days)
  • If bluebird: Enjoy those long groomers and tree runs
  • Link Chair + Gondola run in most conditions

docs.title: Alternative Plan (If Furano Disappoints)
docs.text:
• We have cars = can pivot to Asahidake early (1hr drive)
  • Furano's lower snowfall means some seasons are lean
  • Don't get locked in — flexibility is key

docs.title: KOKUSETSU HOROTACHI
docs.text: Base: Nayoro Onsen Sunpillar

docs.title: Quick Stats
docs.text:
• Size: Tiny (4 runs, 1 lift)
  • Suitable for: Half-day to full-day visit
  • Annual snowfall: ~13m (Horokanai town average)
  • Vertical: 217m (150m - 367m elevation)
  • Top elevation: 367m
  • Best for: Powder gem, local vibe, steep terrain for advanced riders
  • Trail Map: View Map
  • Season: Mid-Dec to late March (sporadic from late Feb onward — check before going!)

docs.title: From Our Accommodation
docs.text:
Base: Nayoro Onsen Sunpillar (Nayoro) Distance: ~76km southwest Travel time: ~1hr 20min Route: Nayoro → Route 275 (south) → Horokanai → 2km west to ski area Google Maps: View route

Parking: - Free parking at base (very close to day lodge and lift) - Small lot but uncrowded - Easy access

Route notes: - Straight shot south on Route 275 - Well-maintained winter roads - Horokanai town is 2km from ski area - Check operating hours before driving! Resort may close early or operate limited days in late season (Fri-Sun only from late Feb)

docs.title: ⚠️ OFF-PISTE POLICY: FORBIDDEN (Strictly Enforced!)
docs.text: This is critical for us: - Off-piste skiing NOT ALLOWED between courses or in sidecountry - Staff are known as "off-piste Nazis" (Powderhounds' words, not ours!) - Similar to old-school Furano (pre-2010s) - You WILL be reprimanded if caught in trees - Visible areas (under chairlift, skier's right of chair) = absolute no-go zones

docs.title: The Trees Are Excellent... But
docs.text:
Despite the ban, the tree skiing here is legendary among powder freaks: - Well-spaced trees with good pitch - Deep, cold, dry snow (town averages -13°C in winter) - Gullies and creeks require navigation skills - Some zones have easy ingress/egress, others are technical

Our approach: - Respect the rules (it's their mountain) - Stick to the two ungroomed courses for powder fun - The "Powder Line" (Horotachi Course) is steep and legitimate - If conditions warrant breaking rules, be invisible and accept full self-responsibility

docs.title: Why Powder Freaks Drive Here
docs.text:
• Extreme cold = best snow quality

    • Horokanai winter avg: -13°C
    • Dec 31, 2020: -32.6°C recorded
    • Record low: -41.2°C (coldest in Japan)
    • Snow is bone-dry, zero moisture

  • Heavy snowfall

    • ~13m annual average
    • 2015: 120cm fell in ONE DAY
    • 2018: 326cm max depth recorded
    • Special Heavy Snowfall Designated Area

  • Low competition

    • Local town population: 1,500 people
    • Even on powder days, rarely crowded
    • 7-8 people total on spring weekdays (per Mojane report)

docs.title: Best Strategy for Feb 11
docs.text:
Timing: - Hit it early if fresh snow overnight - Low elevation + southeast aspect = sun-affected by afternoon - If warm temps, snow quality can sour quickly

Runs to prioritize: - Horotachi Course (ungroomed powder line) — first! - Shirakaba Course (ungroomed trees) — second priority - Karamatsu Course (groomed but steep) — warm-up/recovery

Conditions to expect: - Late season (Feb 11) may be icy in AM, softening by midday - Check operating schedule — may only be open Fri-Sun by then - If sun comes out, snow quality deteriorates fast (low elevation, sunny aspect)

docs.title: DON'T MISS
docs.text:
1. Horotachi Course (ほろたちコース) [ADVANCED] - The main event — this is THE run - Ungroomed steep powder line - 700m length, 44° maximum gradient (yes, seriously), 25° average - Dubbed "Powder Line" by locals - Gets tracked fast on powder days but uncrowded compared to famous resorts - Skier's left of chairlift - Snowboarder note: Steep enough for speed, but watch for flat spots at bottom

2. Shirakaba Course (しらかばコース) [ADVANCED/INTERMEDIATE] - Second powder option - 720m length, 26° max, 17° average - Ungroomed with trees - Slightly mellower than Horotachi but still technical - Visible from parking lot - Requires short uphill boot to access from top of lift - Similar to Sapporo Kokusai's Daskin course but wider and steeper

docs.title: GOOD FOR RECOVERY
docs.text:
3. Karamatsu Course (からまつコース) [INTERMEDIATE] - Groomed cruiser - 800m length, 26° max, 15° average - Used for giant slalom races - Perfect for warming up or tired legs - Upper section mellower, lower section gets steep - Great for carving practice

4. Rinkan Course (林間コース) [BEGINNER/INTERMEDIATE] - ONLY beginner-friendly option (sort of) - Longest run: 1,100m - 18° max, 10° average - Runs along mountain ridge - Wide, gentle cruising - But: One short steep section at end (challenging for true beginners) - Fun features: natural walls/hits along sides

docs.title: SKIPPABLE
docs.text: Nothing! It's only 4 runs, ski them all.

docs.title: LUNCH (Day Lodge Cafeteria)
docs.text:
Style: Classic no-frills Japanese ski cafeteria - All facilities in one room of the day lodge - Very affordable pricing - Simple menu: curry rice, ramen, udon, katsu, snacks - Fresh-cooked meals - Vending machines available - Panoramic views of all slopes from window seats

Seating: - Window counter seats (best views) - Table seats - Tatami mat area (traditional floor seating)

Pricing: Incredibly cheap (even by Japanese standards) - Curry rice: ~¥500-700 (estimate) - Ramen/udon: ~¥600-800 - Way cheaper than typical resort prices

docs.title: BETTER OPTION: Soba in Town
docs.text:
Horokanai = Japan's #1 soba production area!

If you finish skiing early (or resort closes at 15:45), drive into Horokanai town (2km) for authentic buckwheat noodles:

Recommended shops: - Horokanai Soba Setsugekka (そば雪月花) - Tabelog listed - Uses local stone-ground flour

  • Hachiemon (八右衛門)

    • Handmade soba specialist
    • Two types: nihachi-soba (80% buckwheat) and jyuwari (100% buckwheat)
    • Tempura + soba combo highly recommended

  • Michi-no-Eki Soba Restaurant (at roadside station)

    • Convenient on route
    • See "Nearby Attractions" below

docs.title: PRICES (2025-26 Season)
docs.text: Pass Type Adult Jr/Sr High Elementary 1 Day ¥3,500 ¥2,600 ¥2,100 4 Hour Available (price TBD)

docs.title: KEY NOTES
docs.text:
• Cash only — purchase at vending machine
  • Season passes are ridiculously cheap (cheaper than 1-day pass at any major US resort!)
  • Operating hours: 9:00 AM - 4:00 PM (16:00)
  • ⚠️ Check before driving! May close earlier or operate limited days in late Feb/March
  • Late season: Often Fri-Sun only
  • No fancy infrastructure (no lessons, childcare, rentals, etc.)
  • Phone for GPS: 0165-35-3410

docs.title: ⚠️ LATE SEASON OPERATIONS
docs.text:
BIG ISSUE for Feb 11: - Season typically ends late March - From late February onward: Resort may only open Fri-Sun - Operating hours may end earlier than posted - Always call ahead: 0165-35-3410 - Weather-dependent closures (spring warmth, low snow)

Our visit is a Wednesday (Feb 11) — MUST CONFIRM IT'S OPEN!

docs.title: 🌡️ LOW ELEVATION + SUNNY ASPECT
docs.text:
• Base: 150m, Top: 367m (very low!)
  • Southeast facing = sun exposure
  • On warm/sunny days, snow quality deteriorates fast
  • Better choice for brutal weather days when higher resorts (Asahidake, Kurodake) have wind holds
  • Best in cold, snowy, overcast conditions

docs.title: 🚫 OFF-PISTE ENFORCEMENT
docs.text:
• Already covered above, but worth repeating:
  • Strict patrol of tree zones
  • No backcountry access (despite gates/touring potential on Santo-zan nearby)
  • Respect the rules or accept consequences

docs.title: 🏔️ SMALL SCALE
docs.text:
• 1 chairlift (fixed double, no safety bar)
  • 4 courses total
  • Won't hold attention for multi-day visit
  • Perfect for a half-day or single-day visit (which is exactly our plan!)
  • Lift blares music and "don't go off-course" announcements (charmingly retro)

docs.title: 🏪 NO VILLAGE / LIMITED FACILITIES
docs.text:
• Day lodge only (no resort village)
  • Accommodation on-site: Horotachi Sanso (basic lodge)
  • No rentals, no lessons, no childcare
  • Bring everything you need

docs.title: 🍜 Horokanai Soba (MUST DO!)
docs.text:
Why: Japan's #1 buckwheat production area Distance: 2km from ski area (in Horokanai town center) Time needed: 30-60 minutes

Famous for: - "Snow falls twice in Horokanai" — referring to white buckwheat fields in summer - Premium stone-ground flour - Traditional handmade noodles

Where to eat: - See "On-Mountain Food" section above for restaurant recommendations - Michi-no-Eki roadside station has soba restaurant (see below)

docs.title: 🛁 Michi-no-Eki Seiwa Onsen Luonto
docs.text:
Full name: Michi-no-Eki Mori-to-Mizuumi-no-sato Horokanai (政和温泉ルオント) Distance: ~12km north of Horokanai town on Route 275 Why visit: Onsen + soba restaurant combo, perfect post-ski stop

Facilities: - Tranquil onsen with open-air bath - Soba restaurant (local buckwheat) - Roadside station amenities - Budget cabins (closed in winter)

On route? YES — between Horotachi and Nayoro (our hotel) Time needed: 1 hour for bath + meal Good for: Post-ski soak before returning to hotel

docs.title: 🏞️ Lake Shumarinai (朱鞠内湖)
docs.text:
Type: Japan's largest artificial lake Distance: ~20km from Horotachi Why visit: Stunning fjord-like scenery, winter activities

Winter highlights: - Smelt ice fishing (Jan-Apr) - Frozen lake scenery - Phantom fish "Itou" (Sakhalin taimen) habitat - Scenic viewpoints

Access: - Drive via Route 275 - Multiple viewpoints around lake

Accommodation nearby: - Lake House Shumarinai (lakeside hotel/restaurant)

Worth the detour? Only if we have extra time and want scenic break Better for: Summer/fall visits (buckwheat fields, camping, fishing)

docs.title: 🍺 Breweries/Distilleries
docs.text: No significant breweries or distilleries on the Nayoro-Horotachi route. Alternative: Focus on soba and onsen instead (more unique to this area).

docs.title: Snowboarders
docs.text:
✅ Good news: - Horotachi and Shirakaba courses are steep enough for speed - No significant flat sections on main powder lines - Tree spacing is good (where accessible)

⚠️ Challenges: - Rinkan course may have flat spots - Off-piste is forbidden (normally where boards shine) - Only 1 lift = limited terrain

Verdict: Fun for a day, especially if fresh snow. The steep ungroomed runs make it worthwhile.

docs.title: Last Ski Day Vibes
docs.text: This is our final day on snow! 🎿 - Small, local, low-key atmosphere = perfect way to wind down - Less intense than Asahidake/Kurodake - Enjoy the powder gem without crowds - Post-ski soba and onsen = cultural sendoff - Drive back to Nayoro for final onsen dinner at hotel

docs.title: Crowd Strategy
docs.text:
• Town population: 1,500 people
  • Even powder days are uncrowded
  • Feb 11 is a Wednesday — if open, may have resort to ourselves
  • Low competition for fresh tracks

docs.title: Weather Backup
docs.text: If Horotachi is closed or conditions are poor: - Option 1: Return to Nayoro Piyashiri (skied Feb 10) - Option 2: Drive to Wassamu (31km east, 30min) - Option 3: Skip skiing, explore Horokanai soba culture + Lake Shumarinai

docs.text: Base: Court Hotel Asahikawa

docs.title: Quick Stats
docs.text:

  • Annual snowfall: ~8m (Central Hokkaido quality)

Parking: - Free parking at ropeway base (60 cars) - Rarely crowded — empty car park = powder day confirmed!

Route notes: - Scenic drive through Daisetsuzan National Park approach - Well-maintained Route 39 (main highway) - Sounkyo Gorge is spectacular (100m cliffs on both sides) - ⚠️ CRITICAL: Check ropeway status before leaving — often closed for wind/weather - Status page: Kurodake Ropeway (Japanese) - Call ahead: 01658-5-3031

docs.title: Off-Piste Policy
docs.text: ✅ FULLY ALLOWED — This is THE place for it! - No rope enforcement — patrollers won't chase you - Off-piste and backcountry are the entire point of Kurodake - ⚠️ NO AVALANCHE CONTROL — you're 100% on your own - Must have proper backcountry gear (beacon, shovel, probe) - Highly recommended: hire a guide (terrain is cliff-riddled and complex)

docs.title: Terrain Zones
docs.text:
Zone 1: Under the Ropeway (670m-1,300m) - Cliff-riddled, very steep tree skiing - Technical chutes and couloirs - HARD routefinding — cliffs funnel you into specific lines - Gets tracked quickly despite low crowds (limited options) - Some shelter from wind/sun (holds snow quality better) - ⚠️ GUIDE HIGHLY RECOMMENDED — wrong turn = cliff/death or brutal hike

Zone 2: Under the Chairlift (1,300m-1,520m) - 2 groomed runs (beginner-friendly) - Mellow off-piste - ⚠️ VERY FLAT — not ideal for snowboards - Good views but not worth the trip alone

Zone 3: Summit Skin Terrain (1,520m-1,984m) - Moderately pitched sub-alpine terrain - Well-spaced trees, fun angle for powder - More exposed to wind (can get slabby) - Epic views on bluebird days - ⚠️ Backcountry skills required — no patrol, no control

docs.title: Hot Tips: Powder Stashes & Tree Runs

docs.text: Kurodake is not like other Hokkaido resorts. This is: - The steepest terrain in Hokkaido - Unpredictable and often closed - Requires advanced skills and route-finding - Best visited with a guide unless you're very experienced

docs.title: Powder Strategy
docs.text:
• Morning weather check is CRITICAL — ropeway often closed for wind
  • If it's running, GO EARLY — tracks fill in fast (despite low crowds)
  • Focus on ropeway terrain for steep trees and technical lines
  • Bring helmet, beacon, shovel, probe — non-negotiable
  • GPS/topo map app recommended — easy to get lost/cliffed out

• Terrain is complex, cliff-riddled, avalanche-prone
  • Routefinding under ropeway is hard (even for experienced riders)
  • Visibility often terrible
  • Private guides available from Furano (White Room Tours)
  • Multi-day tours occasionally include Kurodake (flexible itineraries)

docs.title: 🎿 RENTALS = JOKE
docs.text:
• Geared for tourists/beginners (rear-entry boots from 1980s)
  • No snowboard rentals
  • No backcountry gear rentals
  • Bring your own gear or rent in Asahikawa/Furano before coming

docs.title: 🏨 SOUNKYO TOWN
docs.text:
• Not a cute onsen village (multi-story concrete hotels)
  • Limited nightlife/restaurants
  • Main activities: skiing, onsen, ice festival (late Jan-March)

docs.title: 🥃 Otokoyama Sake Brewery Museum
docs.text: Distance: 15min from Court Hotel Asahikawa (on way to Kurodake) Location: Nagayama, Asahikawa Why visit: 350 years of sake history, free museum, free tastings, brewery-exclusive bottles Highlights: - Beautiful Edo-period ukiyo-e collection (Hokusai, Utamaro, Kuniyoshi) - Free sake tastings (seasonal & museum-limited varieties) - "Water of Longevity" spring water (free, bring bottles) - Japanese garden (summer) / Ochoco Square playground Hours: 9:00-17:00 daily (closed Dec 31-Jan 3) Admission: FREE Time needed: 45-60 minutes Website: otokoyama.com/museum Note: Perfect stop on way home from Kurodake

docs.title: 🍶 Takasago Sake Brewery
docs.text: Distance: Central Asahikawa (~10min from hotel) Why visit: Traditional 1909 building, historic Asahikawa brewery Note: Less touristy than Otokoyama, local favorite

docs.title: 🛁 Kurodake no Yu (Public Onsen)
docs.text: Location: Sounkyo town center Type: Public bath house with indoor/outdoor baths Views: Limited but nice Price: ~¥800-1,000 Time needed: 1 hour Note: Perfect après-ski if we're staying in Sounkyo area

docs.title: 🏨 Hotel Onsens (Day Use)
docs.text: Location: Various hotels in Sounkyo Price: ~¥1,000 for day-use access Note: Many large hotels open baths to non-guests during daytime

docs.title: 💧 Ginga no Taki & Ryusei no Taki (Twin Waterfalls)
docs.text: Distance: 3km east of Sounkyo (5min drive) Why visit: 100m cascading waterfalls ("Milky Way Falls" & "Shooting Star Falls") Viewing: Large parking lot across river Winter note: Frozen in winter (spectacular!) Time needed: 15-30 minutes

docs.title: 🪨 Obako Rock Formation
docs.text: Distance: 8km east of Sounkyo (10min drive) Why visit: Dramatic rock formations resembling folding screens Note: On the way to Kurodake from Asahikawa

docs.title: ❄️ Sounkyo Ice Waterfall Festival
docs.text: Dates: Late Jan - Mid March (Jan 24 - Mar 8, 2026) Our visit: Feb 6 — FESTIVAL WILL BE RUNNING! Admission: ¥1,000 Highlights: - Multi-story ice structures with tunnels and caverns - Ice sculptures and snow domes - Snow tubing - Fireworks on select evenings (check schedule) - Illuminated at night (most impressive) Location: Festival grounds in Sounkyo Hours: Evenings (illuminated) Time needed: 1-2 hours Note: Good option if ropeway is closed or we finish early

docs.title: Is This Trip Worth It?
docs.text:
PROS: - If conditions align: some of the best steep tree skiing in Hokkaido - Almost zero crowds (empty car park = powder heaven) - Off-piste paradise (no rope enforcement) - Unique Hokkaido experience (this is NOT typical Japanese skiing) - Sounkyo Gorge scenery is spectacular

CONS: - High risk of closure (wind, weather, ava conditions) - Requires advanced skills (not suitable for whole group) - Needs guide for safety + finding best lines - 90min drive from Asahikawa (long day trip) - Limited terrain without skinning

docs.title: Decision Framework
docs.text:
GO if: - ✅ Weather is good (check morning-of) - ✅ Ropeway is confirmed running - ✅ Fresh snow in last 24-48hrs (makes the drive worth it) - ✅ We can hire a guide (safety + line knowledge) - ✅ Group is comfortable with expert terrain

SKIP if: - ❌ Ropeway closed or forecast is bad - ❌ No fresh snow (tracked steep trees = not fun) - ❌ Group wants mellow laps (go to Kamui or Pippu instead) - ❌ Can't secure a guide (safety concern)

docs.title: Backup Plan Options (Feb 6)
docs.text:
If Kurodake doesn't pan out:

  • Kamui Ski Links (40min from Asahikawa) — underrated gem, good tree zones
  • Asahidake (return visit) — ropeway may be more reliable than Kurodake
  • Otokoyama Sake Brewery day — tour, tastings, Asahikawa ramen lunch
  • Sounkyo Ice Festival + onsen — still worth the drive for culture/relaxation

docs.title: Snowboarder Considerations
docs.text:
• ⚠️ Chairlift terrain is FLAT (not worth it for boards)
  • Ropeway terrain is steep but VERY technical (tight trees)
  • Only attempt if:
  • You're very strong in steep, tight trees
  • Snow is light and dry (heavy = hard to turn in time)
  • You're okay with high consequence terrain
  • If in doubt, sit this one out and go to Kamui instead

docs.title: Suggested Itinerary (Feb 6)
docs.text:
Plan A: Full Kurodake Day - 7:00am: Check weather + ropeway status - 8:30am: Depart Asahikawa (if conditions good) - 10:00am: Arrive Kurodake, buy tickets - 10:30am-3:00pm: Ski (hire guide if possible) - 3:30pm: Depart for Asahikawa - 4:00pm: Stop at Otokoyama Sake Brewery - 5:30pm: Return to hotel - 6:30pm: Dinner at Sukiyaki Sankousha (already booked)

Plan B: Kurodake Closed - Morning: Kamui Ski Links (40min away) - Afternoon: Otokoyama Sake Brewery tour + tastings - Evening: Dinner at Sukiyaki Sankousha

Plan C: Weather Terrible Everywhere - Asahikawa exploration day - Otokoyama + Takasago sake breweries - Asahikawa Ramen Village - Shopping/rest before final northern push

docs.title: MOUNT RACEY (YUBARI RESORT)
docs.text: Base: Tomamu The Tower (checking out after skiing)

docs.title: Quick Stats
docs.text:
• Size: Small (4-5 lifts, 18 trails)
  • Suitable for: Half-day visit, morning powder session
  • Annual snowfall: ~8m (315 inches average)
  • Vertical: 408m (1,326 ft)
  • Elevation: 294m base, 702m summit
  • Best for: Tree skiing, powder stashes, uncrowded runs, stormy-day backup
  • Trail Map: View Map

docs.title: From Our Accommodation
docs.text:
Base: Tomamu The Tower (leaving after skiing) Distance: ~85km Travel time: ~1.5 hours Route: Tomamu → Route 38 → Route 274 west → Yubari Google Maps: View route

After skiing: Drive to Asahikawa (~100km, ~1.5-2 hours) Full day route: Tomamu → Mt Racey → Asahikawa (~185km total, ~3-3.5 hours driving + skiing)

Parking: - Free parking at resort base - Easy access near Shuttle Base building

Strategic Note: This is a transition day — ski the morning at Mt Racey, then drive to Asahikawa for our next phase. Pack cars before leaving Tomamu!

docs.title: Off-Piste Policy
docs.text: ✅ ALLOWED — Tree skiing is actively encouraged! - Multiple "in-bounds" tree zones - Some sidecountry available (not officially marked) - No pass-pulling for skiing trees within resort boundary - Powderhounds says: "Either side of 'Thrilling Line' is where the real thrills are"

docs.title: Sidecountry/Backcountry
docs.text:
• Some sidecountry accessible, but not well-documented
  • ⚠️ Not for us (we're just here for a quick morning session)

docs.title: In-Bounds Trees
docs.text:
• This is the highlight — well-spaced trees, powder stashes
  • Often untouched due to low crowds (mostly school groups)
  • Sheltered and lower elevation = good for stormy days
  • Snowboarder-friendly tree spacing

docs.title: Hot Tips: Powder Stashes & Tree Runs
Best Tree Zones (Snowboarder-Friendly)
docs.text:
Based on Powderhounds + local beta:

  • Either side of "Thrilling Line"

    • Official course is boring (7° average pitch), but the trees are gold
    • Well-spaced, powder holds well
    • Feeds back to main lifts

  • "In-bounds" tree zones throughout

    • Not heavily marked, but patrolled
    • Look for natural gaps in tree cover
    • Very few people ski these — you'll likely have them to yourself

  • Off-piste stashes

    • Multiple unmarked powder zones
    • Low visitation = fresh tracks hours after snowfall

docs.title: Powder Strategy
docs.text:
• 🎿 Arrive early — we want first tracks before the school groups
  • 🌨️ Low crowds — powderhounds report "you'll have the powder all to yourself"
  • 🌲 Focus on trees — on-piste is tame, trees are where the fun is
  • ⚠️ Gondola closed — Shuttle 6 gondola is NOT operating 2025-26 season (maintenance)
  • 💨 Wind backup — lower elevation + sheltered = good option when other resorts blow out

docs.title: Terrain Notes
docs.text:
• On-piste: 20% beginner, 40% intermediate, 40% "advanced" (but not challenging)
  • Real terrain: Trees, off-piste, natural features
  • "Expert" runs: Marketing fluff — one hits 45° for a second, most are easy
  • For us: Skip the groomers, hunt the trees

docs.title: DON'T MISS
docs.text:
• Tree zones on both sides of Thrilling Line — best powder stashes
  • Any in-bounds trees — uncrowded, great snow
  • Early morning laps — beat the school groups

docs.title: SKIPPABLE
docs.text:
• Thrilling Line (official course) — ironically not thrilling (7° average pitch)
  • Beginner zones — we're here for powder, not learner slopes

docs.title: RECOVERY RUNS
docs.text:
• Intermediate groomers — easy cruisers if legs are tired from Tomamu
  • Lower elevation runs — mellow, scenic

docs.title: LUNCH (Limited Options)
docs.text:
• Restaurant Tanpopo (たんぽぽ) (Center House, 1F)

    • ⭐ Only real restaurant option
    • Hours: 11:00-14:00
    • Menu: Curry rice, ramen, ankake yakisoba (thick noodle stir-fry)
    • ⚠️ Cash only — ticket vending machine
    • Nice views of the slopes
    • Simple, cheap ski cafeteria food

  • Snow Style Cafe (Shuttle Base)

    • Hours: 10:00-16:00
    • Light snacks and drinks
    • Quick refuel option

docs.title: SNACKS & DRINKS
docs.text:
• Vending machines at Shuttle Base and Center House
  • Basic cafe offerings (coffee, hot chocolate, light snacks)

docs.title: RECOMMENDATION
docs.text: Since this is a quick morning session, consider: - Early breakfast at Tomamu before leaving - Light snack at cafe if needed - Save proper lunch for the drive to Asahikawa

docs.text: 4-hour pass is perfect — we're not staying all day. Saves ¥1,200 per adult vs full-day pass.

docs.title: ⚠️ GONDOLA CLOSED THIS SEASON
docs.text: BIG CHANGE: Shuttle 6 gondola (6-person) is NOT operating 2025-26 season due to maintenance - Sky Station (mountain top building) is also closed - Lifts operating: Beginners 4 (quad), Dancers 4 (quad), Swingers 2 (double) - Racers 2 lift is also closed - Impact: Reduced uphill capacity, but less terrain closed (trees still accessible)

docs.title: 💀 DESTITUTE TOWN VIBES
docs.text:
• Yubari was a coal-mining town of 120,000, now ~8,000 (mostly elderly)
  • Resort has had financial troubles, hotel at base is closed
  • "Ghost town" atmosphere in Yubari city
  • Why visit? You're supporting a struggling community + uncrowded powder!

docs.title: 🏨 NO ACCOMMODATION
docs.text:
• Hotel Mount Racey (ski-in/out) is CLOSED
  • Hotel Shuparo also closed
  • Only option: Hostel Himawari (old school barracks)
  • For us: N/A — we're staying at Tomamu and leaving after skiing

docs.title: 🌦️ WEATHER ADVANTAGE
docs.text:
• Lower elevation = less wind holds than higher resorts
  • Sheltered location = good backup when Tomamu/Furano blow out
  • Stable weather throughout season (per resort marketing)

docs.title: 👥 CROWDS
docs.text:
• Mostly school groups (identically dressed kids)
  • Very few foreigners (you'll likely be the only ones)
  • Much less crowded than Niseko or other famous resorts
  • Powder stays fresh longer

docs.title: Nearby Attractions (On Travel Path to Asahikawa)
docs.text: Since we're driving Yubari → Asahikawa after skiing, here are worthwhile stops:

docs.title: 🏛️ Yubari Coal Mine Museum
docs.text: Distance: In Yubari city (~10min from resort) Why visit: Local history, understand the town's rise and fall Time needed: 30-45 minutes Worth it? Only if you're into industrial history — otherwise skip to get to Asahikawa

docs.title: 🍈 Yubari Melon
docs.text: What: Yubari is famous for insanely expensive melons (¥2-3 million at auction!) In February: Not melon season (summer crop) Skip it: Not relevant for winter visit

docs.title: 🗺️ Route Options to Asahikawa
docs.text:
Option 1: Direct Route (Recommended) - Yubari → Route 274 → Iwamizawa → Route 12 → Asahikawa - ~100km, ~1.5-2 hours - Fastest, well-maintained winter roads

Option 2: Scenic Route via Furano/Biei - Yubari → Furano → Biei → Asahikawa - ~130km, ~2.5 hours - Biei = stunning winter farmland scenery (patchwork hills, snow-covered fields) - Furano = ski town (we're skiing there Feb 4) - Worth the extra 30min if weather is clear and we have time

docs.title: 🛁 Onsen Stops (On Route)
docs.text:
Asahikawa Onsen (Destination) - Multiple onsen in Asahikawa city - Save onsen for arrival in Asahikawa (we'll be staying 5 nights there)

Furano Onsen (If taking scenic route) - Several onsen in Furano area - Only worthwhile if taking Option 2 route

docs.title: ⏰ Timing Strategy
docs.text:
This is a transition day — balance skiing with travel logistics

Suggested schedule: - 7:00am: Breakfast at Tomamu - 8:00am: Pack cars, check out - 8:30am: Depart Tomamu - 10:00am: Arrive Mt Racey (accounting for 1.5hr drive) - 10:00am-2:00pm: Ski (4 hours) - 2:00pm: Pack up, depart for Asahikawa - 4:00pm: Arrive Asahikawa (accounting for 2hr drive) - 6:30pm: Dinner at こま弦工房 (as per itinerary)

Alternative: If fresh snow, ski until 3pm and push dinner back

docs.title: Snowboarders
docs.text:
• ✅ Tree spacing is excellent (low-density, natural flow)
  • ✅ No flat sections in tree zones
  • ✅ Lower elevation = softer snow (less chance of ice)
  • ✅ Uncrowded = no speed checks

docs.title: Strategy for the Day
docs.text:
Goals: 1. ✅ Get a solid 3-4 hours of tree skiing in fresh pow 2. ✅ Efficiently transition from Tomamu to Asahikawa 3. ✅ Arrive in Asahikawa with time to settle before dinner

What this is NOT: - ❌ Not a full-day resort (too small) - ❌ Not a tourist destination (destitute town) - ❌ Not a luxury experience (basic facilities)

What this IS: - ✅ Uncrowded powder stash - ✅ Great tree skiing - ✅ Logistically smart stop between Tomamu and Asahikawa - ✅ Authentic "local Japan" experience

docs.title: Weather Consideration
docs.text:
• Check Tomamu forecast the night before
  • If Tomamu has fresh snow + good visibility, consider extending Tomamu and skipping Mt Racey
  • If Tomamu is windy/poor visibility, Mt Racey is the smart play (lower elevation, sheltered)
  • Flexibility is key — don't lock into Mt Racey if Tomamu is dumping

docs.title: Indy Pass Note
docs.text: Mount Racey is on the Indy Pass (as of 2025-26 season) - This may bring more international visitors in future years - Currently still very local/uncrowded - Good sign for resort's financial viability

docs.title: NAYORO PIYASHIRI
docs.text: Base: Nayoro Onsen Sunpillar (Ski-in/Ski-out!)

docs.title: Quick Stats
docs.text:
• Size: Small (3 lifts, 12-13 runs)
  • Suitable for: 1-2 day stay (perfect for our itinerary)
  • Annual snowfall: ~12m
  • Vertical: 480m
  • Top elevation: 673m
  • Base elevation: 193m
  • Trail Map: View Map
  • Best for: Remote powder stashes, tree runs, uncrowded terrain, authentic local experience
  • Unique claim: "Best snow quality in Hokkaido" — "silky snow" created by extreme cold (-30°C)

docs.title: From Our Accommodation
docs.text:
Base: Nayoro Onsen Sunpillar (AT THE RESORT!) Distance: 0km — ski-in/ski-out Previous location: Court Hotel Asahikawa (Feb 4-9) Drive to Nayoro: ~89km, 1.5-2 hours Route: Asahikawa → Route 40 north → Nayoro (8km to resort) Google Maps: View route

Parking: - Free parking at resort base - Not needed — we're staying on-site!

Route notes: - Final accommodation before heading south to Sapporo - 3 nights at Sunpillar (Feb 9-12) with dinner included - Feb 9: Wassamu Higashiyama ski day, then drive to Nayoro - Feb 10: Nayoro Piyashiri (this profile) - Feb 11: Kokusetsu Horotachi ski day - Feb 12: Transit back to Sapporo

docs.title: Off-Piste Policy
docs.text: ⚠️ RESTRICTED — This is important! - Sidecountry/backcountry: OUT OF BOUNDS - Resort patrol has a reputation for being hostile to rope duckers - "Roped to within an inch of its life" (TGR forums) - ❌ No pass-pulling tolerance — stick to marked areas

docs.title: IN-BOUNDS Tree Run Areas
docs.text:
✅ 4 DESIGNATED TREE RUN ZONES — This is huge for a small resort! Official tree run areas (marked on trail map): - エリアⅠ (Area I) — Operating 9:00-15:00 - エリアⅡ (Area II) — Operating 9:00-15:00 - エリアⅢ (Area III) — Operating 9:00-15:00 (newest addition, opened 2025!) - フリーエリア (Free Area) — Operating 9:00-15:20

Key feature: One tree run is ~1,400m long — marketed as 道内最長クラス (longest class in Hokkaido for in-bounds tree skiing)

docs.title: Trail Breakdown
docs.text:
• 33% beginner
  • 44% intermediate
  • 22% advanced
  • 2 advanced marked trails (including "壁" = "The Wall")
  • Ungroomed zones available
  • Small terrain park

docs.title: Hot Tips: Powder Stashes & Tree Runs
The Piyashiri Advantage
docs.text: 🌨️ "SILKY SNOW" — Resort claims best snow quality in Hokkaido - Temperature regularly drops to -20°C to -30°C in early Feb - Creates ultra-light, dry powder (even lighter than typical Hokkaido powder!) - Low humidity + extreme cold = "silky snow" phenomenon - Diamond dust and sun pillar phenomena common at these temps

docs.title: Best Tree Zones (Snowboarder-Friendly)
docs.text:
Based on official map + specialist reports:

  • Tree Run Area III (newest, opened June 2025)

    • Freshest addition to the resort
    • Likely less tracked than Areas I & II
    • Check signage for specific access points

  • 1,400m Tree Run (one of Areas I-III)

    • Longest in-bounds tree run in Hokkaido
    • Significant vertical descent
    • Feeds back to lifts
    • ⚠️ Note early closure time (3pm)

  • Free Area (フリーエリア)

    • Ungroomed natural terrain
    • More flexibility than numbered areas
    • Operates until 3:20pm (latest of tree zones)

docs.title: Powder Strategy
docs.text:
• ✅ Uncrowded = fresh tracks last longer (only 30,000 people in entire city!)
  • ✅ Off the gaijin radar — you'll likely be the only foreigners
  • ⚠️ Hit tree areas early (close at 3pm, earlier than main lifts)
  • ⚠️ Respect ropes — patrol is strict
  • ⚠️ Check trail map at base for tree run entry points

docs.title: Cold Weather Strategy
docs.text:
• DRESS WARM — This is the coldest resort on our trip
  • -20°C to -30°C is possible in early Feb mornings
  • Face masks, hand warmers, layering essential
  • Take warming breaks at Log Panorama (mid-mountain café)
  • Onsen access at base = perfect recovery

docs.title: DON'T MISS
docs.text:
• The 1,400m Tree Run — longest in Hokkaido, bucket list item
  • Tree Run Area III — newest terrain (2025)
  • 壁 (The Wall) — steepest marked run (32° max slope)
  • 樹氷コース (Frost Tree Course) — scenic run through frost-covered trees
  • イースタンコース (Eastern Course) — can be a powder field if Lift 4 is closed

docs.title: BEST FOR SNOWBOARDERS
docs.text:
• Tree areas are spaced well (not too tight)
  • Good vertical in tree zones
  • Minimal flat sections in advanced terrain

docs.title: RECOVERY RUNS
docs.text:
• 一般ゲレンデ第1・第2 (General Slopes 1 & 2) — mellow cruisers, full vertical
  • ジャイアントコース第1・第2 (Giant Courses 1 & 2) — wide, groomed intermediates
  • 林間コース (Forest Course) — gentle scenic run through trees

docs.title: SKIPPABLE
docs.text:
• Terrain park — described as "primitive" features
  • Beginner zone — not our focus

docs.title: LUNCH (Base Area Restaurant)
docs.text:
Main Cafeteria (120-person capacity, operating 11:00-16:00, LO 15:30) ⭐ Top value in Hokkaido — dirt-cheap prices!

Recommended Dishes: - Ramen (味噌・塩・醤油) — ¥850 - Miso, salt, or soy sauce varieties - Classic warming ski lunch

  • Katsu Curry — ¥1,300

    • Perfect hearty meal after cold morning laps

  • Chashu-don (味噌汁付) — ¥950

    • Pork rice bowl with miso soup
    • Good value, filling

  • 本マグロ丼 — ¥1,700

    • Bluefin tuna bowl (premium option)
    • Fresh seafood surprise at a ski resort!

Budget Options: - Kake soba/udon — ¥650 - Curry rice — ¥700 - Gyudon — ¥850

Side Menu: - Karaage (fried chicken) — ¥350 - Curry pan — ¥400 - Nikuman (pork bun) — ¥250 - Soft cream — ¥400

docs.title: MID-MOUNTAIN
docs.text: Log Panorama (ゲレンデ中腹) - Scenic log cabin halfway up - Light snacks, coffee, warming break - Perfect spot to escape extreme cold - "ぬくもりある空間" (warm, cozy atmosphere)

docs.title: PRICES (2025-26 Season)
docs.text:
⭐ CHEAPEST RESORT ON OUR TRIP

Pass Type Adult Senior (60+) Notes 1 Day ¥3,700 ¥2,300 Web price 1 Point ¥360 ¥360 Per ride 2 Point ¥720 ¥720 2 rides 3 Point ¥1,080 ¥1,080 3 rides

docs.title: KEY NOTES
docs.text:
• ¥500 deposit for IC card (WAKO system) — refundable
  • Web purchase available: https://nayoropiyashiri.axess.shop/en/Products/Tickets/
  • Can skip ticket window by buying online + using pickup box
  • Night skiing available (separate pricing)
  • On Indy Pass — honored here!
  • No youth/child pricing shown on web store (ask at window if needed)

Our group: - Adult (under 60): ¥3,700 - Seniors (60+): ¥2,300 — great deal!

Comparison: This is ~1/3 the price of Niseko/Kiroro — incredible value for uncrowded powder!

docs.title: ❄️ EXTREME COLD
docs.text: BIGGEST FACTOR: Prepare for -20°C to -30°C - Coldest resort on our entire trip (latitude 44°N, deep inland) - "Silky snow" only exists because of these temps - Diamond dust and sun pillar phenomena at these temps - Bring: face masks, neck warmers, hand/toe warmers, layering - Plan warming breaks every 60-90 minutes

docs.title: 🚫 STRICT ROPE POLICY
docs.text:
• Patrol is known to be hostile to boundary violations
  • "Roped to within an inch of its life" (TGR forums)
  • Plenty of in-bounds terrain — no need to duck ropes
  • Focus on 4 designated tree areas instead

docs.title: ⏰ EARLY TREE RUN CLOSURES
docs.text:
• Tree areas close at 3:00pm (main lifts run until 4:30pm)
  • Plan tree laps for morning/early afternoon
  • Don't wait until late day for the 1,400m run

docs.title: 🗣️ MINIMAL ENGLISH
docs.text:
• "Barely any English spoken" (Powderhounds)
  • Trail map and lunch menus have some English
  • Use Google Translate for restaurant orders
  • Staff are friendly despite language barrier
  • This is authentic, local Japan — embrace it!

docs.title: 🏔️ SMALL RESORT SCALE
docs.text:
• 3 lifts, 12-13 runs — this is NOT a multi-day destination
  • Perfect for 1-2 days (we have 1 day here, 1 day at Horotachi)
  • Advanced skiers may find on-piste limiting
  • Tree runs are the main attraction for our crew

docs.title: 🌫️ VISIBILITY
docs.text:
• Extreme cold can create ice fog/diamond dust
  • Beautiful but can limit visibility
  • Have a flexible plan if conditions are flat light

docs.title: 🥃 Takasago Sake Brewery
docs.text: Location: Asahikawa (on route from Asahikawa to Nayoro) Distance: 0km detour (in Asahikawa city) Address: 17-1 Miyashitadori, Asahikawa Why visit: Historic sake brewery, tours by reservation, museum with antique artifacts Best for: Stop before leaving Asahikawa on Feb 9 Time needed: 1 hour

docs.title: 🍶 Kunimare Sake Brewery
docs.text: Location: Mashike (coastal town, ~1 hour west of route) Why visit: Northernmost sake brewery in Japan Note: Significant detour — only if we have extra time/interest Time needed: 2 hours including detour

docs.title: 🔭 KITASUBARU Observatory
docs.text:
Location: Nayoro (15min drive from resort) Address: 157-1 Nisshin, Nayoro Hours: 1:00pm - 8:00pm (winter), closed Mondays Admission: ¥410 adult, ¥200 seniors Why visit: - Perfect dark sky location (no light pollution) - 40cm and 50cm telescopes - Planetarium shows (4x daily) - Nayoro is famous for stargazing due to remote location

Timing: Evening after skiing (if clear skies) Note: Late opening (1pm) means skip for morning/lunch, go after dinner

docs.text:

docs.title: Remote Location Advantage
docs.text:
• 89km north of Asahikawa = deepest north we go (besides Horotachi)
  • Off the international ski tourism radar completely
  • "You're unlikely to see gaijin or others competing for fresh powder" (Powderhounds)
  • We'll likely be the only foreigners on the mountain
  • Authentic local experience — dedicated locals only

docs.title: Snowboarders
docs.text:
• ✅ Tree spacing is good in designated areas

docs.title: Accommodation Advantage
docs.text:
• Ski-in/ski-out at Sunpillar = zero commute
  • Roll out of bed, hit first chair

docs.title: Itinerary Context
docs.text:

docs.title: PIPPU SKI AREA
docs.text: Base: Court Hotel Asahikawa

docs.title: Quick Stats
docs.text:
• Size: Small (9 runs, 3 lifts + rope tow)
  • Suitable for: 1 day (perfect recovery resort)
  • Annual snowfall: Lower than major Hokkaido resorts (low elevation)
  • Vertical: 330m
  • Elevation: 250-580m
  • Best for: Recovery skiing, off-piste practice, empty slopes, dirt-cheap skiing
  • Trail Map: View Map

docs.title: From Our Accommodation
docs.text:
Base: Court Hotel Asahikawa Distance: ~26km Travel time: ~35-40 minutes Route: Asahikawa → Route 39 northeast → Pippu Exit: Hokkaido Hifukita IC (3 min from expressway exit) Google Maps: View route

Parking: - Free parking at resort base - Ample space (this place is never crowded)

Route notes: - Straightforward drive on Route 39 - Very close to expressway exit - Well-signed in Japanese (ぴっぷスキー場)

docs.title: Off-Piste Policy
docs.text: ✅ ALLOWED — This is huge for a recovery day! - No pass-pulling risk - Tree skiing permitted (on skier's left side) - Ski patrol used to gaijin in the trees - Perfect for learner powder hounds ("powder puppies")

docs.title: Tree Skiing Zones
docs.text:
• Skier's left of resort — main tree skiing area
  • Mellow pitch
  • Moderately spaced trees (not too tight)
  • Small sections (great for experimenting)
  • Easy to navigate back to lifts

docs.title: Sidecountry
docs.text:
• Very accessible — obvious routes, no Travis Rice skills required
  • Follow summer road for 5-15 min walk/skin
  • Various tree spacing and moderate pitch
  • Egress: 5 min skin or walk along road back to resort
  • ⚠️ We probably won't push it — this is a recovery day!

docs.title: In-Bounds Advanced Runs
docs.text:
• Deep Snow Course (Course #9) — 1,300m, up to 36° pitch, often has actual deep snow
  • Golden Course (Course #8) — 1,200m, 30° max, wild moguls and steep wall

docs.title: Hot Tips: Powder Stashes & Tree Runs
Why Pippu is Perfect for Tired Legs
docs.text:
• Usually empty — often feels like a private resort
  • Short, manageable laps — not exhausting
  • Mellow off-piste — no commitment required
  • Super cheap — won't feel guilty leaving early
  • Onsen next door — soak those legs!

docs.title: Best Tree Zones (Snowboarder-Friendly)
docs.text:
• Skier's left trees (off Deep Snow Course / Golden Course)
  • Well-spaced pines
  • Easy entry/exit
  • Perfect practice zone for tree riding
  • Small zones = low commitment

docs.title: Powder Strategy
docs.text:
• ✅ Fresh tracks last LONGER here (low crowds)
  • Hit trees in morning if there's fresh snow
  • School groups usually stick to Family/Strawberry courses (right side)
  • Defense force training groups = hilarious to watch (old white skis!)

docs.title: Terrain Notes
docs.text:
• On-piste: 30% beginner, 50% intermediate, 20% advanced
  • Real goods: Off-piste trees + Deep Snow Course
  • Longest run: Strawberry Course (2,200m) — mellow cruiser
  • Best for recovery: Family Course (2,000m, 13° average) or Diamond Course

docs.title: DON'T MISS
docs.text:
• Deep Snow Course — if legs permit, this is the most fun on-piste
  • Skier's left trees — perfect for mellow powder practice
  • Strawberry Course — longest run (2,200m), great warm-up

docs.title: PERFECT FOR RECOVERY
docs.text:
• Family Course — 2,000m, 13° average, super mellow
  • Diamond Course — 1,500m, 16° average, "for people who just can't stop skiing"
  • Silver Course — 700m, smooth intermediate cruiser

docs.title: SKIPPABLE
docs.text:
• Beginner Course — very short (400m), 8° — only for absolute beginners
  • Kappa Course — 600m, basically a bunny hill ("mini skiers' home ground")

docs.title: LAPS FOR THE KEEN
docs.text: If someone (Piers?) wants to charge despite it being recovery day: - Repeat Deep Snow Course + Golden Course - Venture into skier's left trees - Explore sidecountry (5-15 min walk out)

docs.title: LUNCH (Best Options)
docs.text:
• Restaurant "Yukibanya" (Central area)

    • ⭐ Top pick: Nijimasu Oyako-don (rainbow trout bowl)
    • Highly rated by locals
    • Uses Pippu-grown rainbow trout (local specialty!)
    • Good value

  • Center House "Skip" (Main lodge)

    • Karaage-don (fried chicken bowl) — popular comfort food
    • Fried Taiyaki — sweet fish-shaped pastry (unique!)
    • Incredibly cheap

docs.title: ⛷️ SMALL RESORT = LIMITED TERRAIN
docs.text:
• You'll ski everything in 2-3 hours
  • Not a destination resort
  • That's the point — perfect recovery day

docs.title: 🌡️ LOW ELEVATION = VARIABLE SNOW
docs.text:
• 250-580m elevation (very low by Hokkaido standards)
  • SW facing aspect (sun can affect snow)
  • BUT: Interior location + frigid temps = usually good quality
  • Fresh snow is best (tracks out slower here anyway)

docs.title: 🏗️ AGING INFRASTRUCTURE
docs.text:
• Yellow single chair is no longer operational
  • Resort is shrinking (like many small Japanese resorts)
  • What remains is well-maintained but basic

docs.title: 🔇 EXTREMELY QUIET
docs.text:

  • Don't expect lively atmosphere

docs.text:

Rating: 4.0★ (796 reviews) Why visit: Perfect post-ski soak, included with lift ticket Type: Hotel onsen open to day visitors Features: - Indoor and outdoor baths - Views over Pippu valley - Very local vibe (not touristy) - Can use even if not staying overnight

docs.text:

Ramen style: Shoyu (soy sauce) based, rich pork bone broth, seafood-heavy Good for: Dinner on the way back to hotel

docs.title: 🎿 Perfect Recovery Day Resort
docs.text: Why Pippu is ideal for Feb 8: - By this point we'll have skied 7 full days (Jan 30 - Feb 7) - Legs will be tired, powder hangovers likely - Pippu = low pressure, cheap, mellow terrain - Can leave early without guilt (so cheap!) - Built-in onsen recovery

docs.text:
• ✅ Tree spacing is perfect (not too tight)
  • ✅ Off-piste zones are board-friendly
  • ✅ No mega-flat sections in best zones
  • ✅ Mellow pitch = easy on tired legs

docs.title: Day Structure Options
docs.text:
Option A: Full Recovery Day - Sleep in (10am arrival) - Buy 4-hour pass (¥3,000 with meal) - Cruise Family/Strawberry courses - Lunch at Yukibanya (rainbow trout bowl!) - Quick trees session if feeling good - Onsen at Yuyu Pippu (1-2 hours) - Early return to Asahikawa for dinner

Option C: Split Group - Keen crew: charge the trees and sidecountry - Recovery crew: cruise blues and onsen early - Regroup for lunch or post-ski onsen - Everyone happy

docs.title: SAHORO RESORT
docs.text: Base: Tomamu The Tower (Hoshino Resorts)

docs.title: Quick Stats
docs.text:
• Size: Medium (21 runs, 9 lifts)
  • Annual snowfall: ~8m (drier/lower than coastal resorts, but high quality)
  • Vertical: 610m (420-1,030m)
  • Top elevation: 1,030m
  • Best for: Intermediates, families, uncrowded groomers, tree skiing
  • Vibe: Quiet, polished, Tokachi Plains views
  • Trail Map: View Map

docs.title: From Our Accommodation
docs.text:
Base: Tomamu The Tower (Hoshino Resorts) Distance: ~32km Travel time: ~30-40 minutes Route: Tomamu → Route 274 east → Sahoro Google Maps: View route

Parking: - Free parking at resort base (gondola station) - Well-marked, easy access - No issues with capacity

Route notes: - Easy highway drive (Route 274) - Well-maintained road - Closest resort to Tomamu (perfect day trip from our base) - Can pair with Furano the next day (continuing west)

docs.title: Off-Piste Policy
docs.text: ⚠️ OFFICIALLY NOT PERMITTED — but enforcement is relaxed - Powderhounds reports: "Ski patrol don't seem too fussed about it" - Japow Travel: "Roped and off-piste zones are enforced" (no gate network) - Reality check: Casual in-bounds tree runs appear tolerated, but ducking ropes = pass pull risk - Our approach: Stick to visible tree zones within marked boundaries, don't push boundaries

docs.title: In-Bounds Tree Skiing
docs.text:
• ✅ Trees throughout the resort (below treeline skiing)
  • Well-spaced evergreens and pines
  • Multiple glades and soft-shoulder features within marked terrain
  • "Little gullies that fill like bowls, micro-spines that collect cold smoke"

docs.title: Terrain Breakdown
docs.text:
• Marked runs: 21 courses (8 beginner, 3 intermediate, 10 advanced)
  • Reality: Advanced runs aren't super challenging (max 39° pitch, but momentary)
  • True difficulty: Depends on moguls and stumps poking through
  • Best terrain: Off-piste tree runs for advanced riders

docs.title: Hot Tips: Powder Stashes & Tree Runs
Powder Strategy
docs.text: ✅ THE BIG WIN: Low crowds = powder longevity - Weekdays feel like private sessions - Fresh tracks often last past lunch (even on weekends) - Most skiers/boarders stick to groomers → trees stay fresh

docs.title: Best Tree Zones (Snowboarder-Friendly)
docs.text:
Based on Japow Travel + Powderhounds:

  • Upper Mountain Tree Runs

    • Access via gondola → high quads
    • Best pitch and fall line
    • Work the fall-line shots early before obvious lines get trenched
    • Even when tracked, dry snow "smears and slarves beautifully"

  • Lee-Side Glades (storm days)

    • Hit protected sides first when wind is up
    • Trees hold snow well despite exposed ridgeline
    • Creep toward exposed spines as wind eases

  • Connector Glades

    • Secret stash fringes between main runs
    • "Pop back to main piste without grinding cat tracks"
    • Locals ignore these → good for afternoon sessions

docs.title: Terrain Notes (Snowboarder-Specific)
docs.text:
• ✅ Well-spaced trees (good for boards)
  • ✅ Long groomers with good fall line
  • ⚠️ Some connector runs can be flat (typical Japan issue)
  • ✅ No crazy traverses to best zones
  • ✅ "Hero-snow carving clinics" on top-to-bottom groomers

docs.title: DON'T MISS
docs.text:
• Gondola → High Quad laps — best vertical, best pitch
  • Tree zones on upper mountain — fall-line shots, dry powder
  • Top-to-bottom groomer runs — "chalk-dry carving clinics" (first chair!)
  • Sahoro Express quad area — services black runs, NNE aspect (holds snow well)

docs.title: GOOD FOR RECOVERY
docs.text:
• Mid-mountain sheltered trails — when visibility tanks
  • Beginner trails — long, gentle, scenic
  • New "Beginners Park" area — snow escalators, mellow terrain (skip unless teaching someone)

docs.title: SKIPPABLE
docs.text:
• Sahoro Express quad — doesn't always operate (frustrating!)
  • Top lift — "almost never operates" (plan on gondola laps for full vertical)
  • Night skiing — mellow carving only, not powder hunting (ends 18:00)

docs.title: LUNCH (Best Options)
docs.text:
• Fomalhaut (Main Gondola Station)

    • ⭐ Top pick for hot meals
    • "Delicious lunch perfect for power charge after skiing"
    • Standard Japanese ski fare: ramen, curry rice, katsu curry, pork bowls
    • Quick, warm, close to lifts
    • Hours: 11:00-15:00

  • Hanamori Kuma Mountain Hut Store

    • Seasonal operation (Dec 20 - Mar 31, 2026)
    • Hours: 10:00-16:00 (last order 15:30)
    • Good for snacks and quick bites

  • Drinks (Cafe)

    • Drinks and sweets for short breaks
    • Hours: 10:00-16:00
    • Think: coffee, hot chocolate, pastries

docs.title: PAID LOUNGE
docs.text: K-Lounge (2nd floor) - ¥2,000 adults, ¥1,500 children - All-you-can-drink coffee, tea, Japanese tea - Reclining chairs, foot massager, newspapers, magazines - Good for mid-day reset or bad weather - Hours: 10:00-16:00

docs.title: OFF-MOUNTAIN
docs.text: Shintoku Town (~15-20min taxi from resort) - Famous for soba noodles (Tokachi region specialty) - "Simple, earthy bowl after a cold-smoke day hits the spot" - Escape the resort if you want more variety

docs.title: ⚠️ LIFT CLOSURES
docs.text: FRUSTRATING: Sahoro Express & top lift often don't run - "Frustrating to figure out which lifts might actually have running on any given day" - Top lift "almost never operates" - Forces gondola laps for full vertical (can get repetitive) - Check lift status at gondola station before committing to zones

docs.title: 🌬️ WIND & WEATHER
docs.text:
• Ridge can scour: Wind affects top mountain
  • Trees hold well: Protected zones preserve quality
  • Tokachi side weather: Colder and clearer post-storm (less maritime moisture)
  • Sunny days common: East/southeast slopes can sun-affect (hit shaded sides first)

docs.title: 🏔️ LOWER SNOWFALL
docs.text:
• ~8m annual (vs. 15-21m at Niseko/Kiroro)
  • Trade-off: Drier, feathery snow quality ("chalky and dry")
  • More southerly storm dependency (less frequent than NW storms)
  • Early season can be thin (we're visiting Feb 3 = mid-season, should be good)

docs.title: 🏨 NO VILLAGE
docs.text:
• Resort complex only (Club Med + Sahoro Resort Hotel)
  • Minimal nightlife (hotel bars/restaurants only)
  • Shintoku town nearby (~15-20min taxi) but basic
  • Our situation: Not an issue since we're staying at Tomamu (just day tripping)

docs.title: 👨‍👩‍👧‍👦 SCHOOL GROUPS
docs.text:
• Gondola queues can happen due to school kids
  • Weekday visits = less of an issue
  • Hit early for first chair advantage

docs.title: 🛁 Tokachigawa Onsen
docs.text: Distance: ~50km east of Sahoro (towards Obihiro) Type: Famous "moor onsen" (plant-based hot spring — rare!) Why visit: Unique amber-colored water, skin-beautifying properties Time needed: 1-2 hours Route: If heading toward Obihiro/Tokachi region (not on our route to Furano)

docs.title: 🛁 Fukiage Open-Air Onsen
docs.text: Distance: ~40km northwest (near Kamifurano) Rating: 4.5★ Type: FREE wild onsen in the mountains Why visit: Mixed bathing, natural setting, adventure experience Note: On route toward Furano (our next day) — good post-ski stop Caution: Very rustic, no facilities, mixed gender

docs.title: 🏔️ Shintoku Town
docs.text: Distance: 15-20min taxi from resort Highlights: - Soba noodles — Tokachi region specialty - Local restaurants (basic but authentic) - Convenience stores for supplies - Escape the resort bubble

docs.title: 🎿 Combine with Tomamu
docs.text: Distance: 32km (30-40min) Strategy: Since we're based at Tomamu, could split the group: - Half-day Sahoro → afternoon at Tomamu - Or full day Sahoro, evening at Tomamu facilities - Tomamu has better dining/nightlife options

docs.title: Snowboarders
docs.text:
• ✅ Tree spacing is excellent for boards
  • ✅ Good fall-line on groomers
  • ✅ No extreme traverses to best zones
  • ⚠️ Some flat connector runs (standard Japan)
  • ✅ Uncrowded = confidence-building terrain

docs.title: Why Sahoro for This Day?
docs.text:
• Close to base: Only 30-40min from Tomamu (easy morning, relaxed pace)
  • Good variety: Mix of groomers and trees
  • Low crowds: Weekday in early Feb = likely quiet
  • Recovery-friendly: Not as intense as Asahidake/Kurodake later in trip
  • Intermediate heaven: Great for mixed-ability group

docs.title: Strategy for the Day
docs.text:
• Early start: First gondola for best tree runs
  • Morning: Hit upper mountain trees while fresh
  • Lunch: Fomalhaut (ramen/curry)
  • Afternoon: Groomers or explore connector glades
  • Evening: Return to Tomamu for dinner at Camaro Steak Diner (18:30 booking)

docs.title: Weather/Conditions Backup
docs.text:
• If Sahoro is windy/poor visibility → stick to Tomamu instead (we're based there)
  • If amazing powder → hit Sahoro hard (low crowds = fresh tracks all day)
  • If mixed group energy → split day between both resorts

docs.title: Resort Philosophy
docs.text:
From Japow Travel:

"Sahoro isn't a headline hog — it's the steady friend who shows up with cold, consistent snow, room to move, and a calm atmosphere that lets you ski more and stress less. docs.text: Base: Hotel WBF Sapporo Chuo (Central Sapporo)

docs.title: Quick Stats
docs.text:
• Size: Small-medium (15 runs, 10 lifts total — Highland Zone has 4 lifts)
  • Suitable for: Full day for powder hounds, half day for cruisers
  • Annual snowfall: ~10m+ (similar to neighboring resorts)
  • Vertical: 683m
  • Top elevation: 1,023m (Mt. Teine summit)
  • Best for: Steep in-bounds terrain, sidecountry/backcountry access, tree skiing
  • Season: Nov 22, 2025 - May 6, 2026 (Highland Zone); weekends/holidays only after April 6
  • Trail Map: Download PDF

docs.title: From Our Accommodation
docs.text:
Base: Hotel WBF Sapporo Chuo (Central Sapporo) Distance: ~20km Travel time: 40-45 minutes Route: Central Sapporo → Route 5 (northwest) → Teine IC → Local roads to Highland Google Maps: View route

Parking: - Free parking at both Highland and Olympia base areas - Highland Zone parking is closer to expert terrain - Well-maintained access roads (standard winter prep)

Route notes: - Shortest drive of entire trip (perfect for first day!) - Highway driving until Teine IC exit - Highland Zone is upper mountain (go here, not Olympia) - Can access via train + bus (JR Sapporo → Teine Station + JR bus, covered by JR Pass)

docs.title: Off-Piste Policy
docs.text: ✅ PERMITTED IN DESIGNATED ZONES - Nature Zone (skier's right of Highland quad) — marked off-piste area with ropes - Wide tree spacing, relatively mellow pitch - Gets tracked quickly (but less than big resorts) - Four sets of ropes mark the boundary (they really want you to notice!) - Standard disclaimers apply: ride at own risk, rescue at own expense - Patrollers are "incredibly lenient" (per Powderhounds) — not pulling passes

docs.title: Backcountry/Sidecountry Gates
docs.text:
🚪 TEINE GATE — Legendary backcountry access near summit - Gate located near Summit Express top terminal - No registration required (ride at own risk stance) - Multiple bowls and chutes accessible - Can ride down to parking area (long run!) - ⚠️ Requires ava gear, experience, and local knowledge - ⚠️ Not for us — we don't have touring/ava equipment

Other sidecountry zones: - Under old cable car line — "rite of passage for expert riders" - First to get tracked - Visible from resort - Skier's left of resort boundary — multiple bowls, some wide chutes - Traversing + side-stepping required - Pink ribbons mark return points - Nasty cliffs if you go wrong (huck zone for pros only!) - Skier's right beyond Nature Zone — exits to road near gondola - Short hike required - Less tracked than other zones

docs.title: In-Bounds Trees
docs.text:
• Nature Zone — best in-bounds tree skiing
  • Beautifully spaced trees (not too tight, not too wide)
  • North facing (powder stays pristine)
  • Consistent fall line
  • Short vertical (legs won't pump out)

docs.title: Hot Tips: Powder Stashes & Tree Runs
Best In-Bounds Tree Zones (Snowboarder-Friendly)
docs.text:
• Nature Zone (permitted off-piste, skier's right)

    • Perfect tree spacing for boards
    • Wide enough to carve, tight enough to be fun
    • North-facing aspect = cold, dry snow
    • Feeds back to Highland lifts
    • Gets tracked by lunch on powder days (but still good)

  • Trees under Kitakabe Course

    • Midway down the "north wall" black run
    • Widely spaced
    • Steep sections (matching the 36° groomed run)
    • Access via Summit Express

  • Olympic Slalom/GS Courses (when left ungroomed)

    • Historic runs from 1972 Olympics
    • Technical terrain, good pitch
    • Bumps develop quickly
    • Great for leg burners

docs.title: Powder Strategy
docs.text:
• Arrive EARLY — 20min from Sapporo = day-trippers arrive fast
  • Hit Nature Zone first — obvious powder zone gets tracked by 11am
  • Sidecountry = advanced only — requires traversing skills and terrain knowledge
  • Consider a guide — local knowledge unlocks the best stashes (gates, pink ribbons, safe lines)
  • Summit views = bonus — stunning panorama of Sapporo city + Ishikari Bay

docs.title: Terrain Notes
docs.text:
• Highland Zone is the goods — don't waste time in Olympia (that's beginner zone)
  • Kitakabe Course — Japan's most iconic steep in-bounds run (36° max pitch)
  • Name literally means "north wall"
  • Develops moguls quickly
  • Half-groomed sometimes
  • Short vertical — 683m means quick laps, but legs don't get torched
  • Gondola = critical — connects Olympia ↔ Highland (last one at 3:45pm/4pm)
  • Miss it = STUCK (no way back to Highland parking!)

docs.title: DON'T MISS (Highland Zone Only!)
docs.text:
• 🔥 Kitakabe Course — 36° steeps, moguls, iconic Japan terrain
  • 🌲 Nature Zone trees — best in-bounds pow stashes
  • 🎿 Olympic Slalom/GS runs — historic, technical terrain
  • 🏔️ Summit Express to top — views + access to steepest terrain

docs.title: SKIPPABLE
docs.text:
• ❌ Entire Olympia Zone — beginner/family terrain (not for us)
  • ❌ Paradise Lift — slow double chair, limited terrain access
  • ❌ Connector run Highland → Olympia — 6km long, flat sections, boring

docs.title: RECOVERY RUNS
docs.text:

  • Green run from summit — narrow trail, steep for a green (good warm-up)

docs.title: 📏 SHORT VERTICAL
docs.text:
