docs.text: Distance: 5min drive from resort (directly on route back to Sapporo) Rating: Local favorite Why visit: Natural hot springs, open-air baths, saunas (including unique "Sea of Clouds Rock Sauna") Special feature: Löyly sauna program (Finnish tradition with aromatic steam) Price: ¥1,100 weekdays, ¥1,200 weekends/holidays Hours: Open 24/7, 365 days/year Time needed: 1-2 hours Perfect for: Post-ski soak before heading back to Sapporo Website: Via skiing-hokkaido.com

docs.text: This is Day 1 of skiing — be smart: - Don't blow legs out immediately (short vertical = manageable) - Warm up on Panorama runs, progress to Kitakabe steeps - Test gear, get ski legs back - Nature Zone trees = good confidence builder - Save energy for 16 more days of skiing!

Base: Tomamu The Tower — True ski-in/ski-out accommodation Distance: 0km (literally at the base of Tower Mountain) Parking: Resort parking included

docs.title: Off-Piste Policy
docs.text:
✅ ALLOWED — with registration required

Official designated off-piste zones: - Multiple marked off-piste areas on both Tower Mountain and Tomamu Mountain - Registration required: Must register at Resort Center before accessing - GPS tracking app: Download required app (allows ski patrol to track location) - Season: Off-piste areas typically open from mid-January onwards - Rating: Resort rates all off-piste as "expert," though realistically they're more advanced (not super steep, no cliffs/cornices)

Off-piste terrain characteristics: - Well-gladed trees (good spacing for snowboards) - Some bamboo obstacles (fun when snow is deep, annoying when it's shallow) - Wedge-shaped zones on Tomamu Mountain side (try to steer you away from creek) - Wide former piste areas on Tower Mountain side (old lift line access via short hike or traverse)

⚠️ Early season note: Resort doesn't get huge early snow volumes like coastal resorts, so expect bamboo navigation in December/early January

docs.title: Sidecountry/Backcountry
docs.text:
✅ PERMITTED — with proper registration

This is a MAJOR highlight of Tomamu!

Top backcountry gate (past Cloud Walk): - PRISTINE POWDER — north-facing aspect (not sun-affected like in-bounds) - ~300m vertical for sidecountry access - Wide open trees where you can fly - Some bushy zones, but navigable - Snowboarders: Extensive traversing required (may get less vertical) - Ski tourers: Can continue to valley floor for full descent (bliss!)

Frontside backcountry gate (via Cloud Walk): - Varied terrain when fresh - Good ski touring/splitboard access to adjacent mountain - Multiple bowls open up with touring setup - Can dabble in trees and pop back in-bounds - Warning: Lower sections are REALLY FLAT (slog for boarders, bring touring gear if possible) - Former ski area below for road/train pickup if you commit

Requirements: - Submit climbing plans at main lodge - Proper avalanche awareness (though Tomamu is not super avalanche-prone) - ⚠️ Not for us if we don't have touring/ava gear — but worth considering hiring guide

docs.title: Hot Tips: Powder Stashes & Tree Runs
Best Strategy
docs.text:
🏔️ The real goods at Tomamu are OUTSIDE the ropes

Powder game plan: - Early AM: Hit sidecountry gates FIRST (top gate = best powder, north-facing aspect) - Mid-morning: Work the designated off-piste zones (trees on Tomamu Mountain side) - Afternoon: If sunny, avoid Tower Mountain front side (south-facing, gets baked) - Powder days: Tower Mountain trees are wide and fun, but quality drops faster in sun

docs.text: ✅ ALLOWED IN DESIGNATED AREAS - Some ungroomed/unmarked zones in the trees (shown in red on course map) - "Sidecountry" zones accessible from lifts - ⚠️ Not all tree zones are official — assess risk yourself - Resort has limited rescue resources (small town-run operation)

docs.title: Tree Zones
docs.text:
Skier's Right (from top of single chair): - Trees of varying spacing - Moderate pitch at top, mellows toward base - Some small creeks, gullies, and a canal to navigate - Can bail early or ride to base - Snowboarder-friendly (not too tight)

Skier's Left (from top): - Fun but less vertical - Shorter runs than right side

docs.text:

  • Intermediate: Most groomed piste

docs.title: Hot Tips: Powder Stashes & Tree Runs
THE WASSAMU SECRET 🤫
docs.text: This is the dream: Opens at 10am (leisurely!) and powder stays untouched until late in the day. Zero crowds. Zero competition. If you've been dealing with tracked-out resorts, this is your therapy day.

docs.title: Powder Strategy
docs.text:
• No rush! — Seriously. Sleep in. The powder will wait.
  • Hit the trees mid-morning — Still untracked at 11am, noon, even 2pm
  • Lap the ungroomed zones (marked red on map) — Locals might not even touch them
  • Single chair = goods — Top lift accesses the best tree zones
  • Explore both sides — Skier's right has more vertical, left is quicker laps

docs.title: Terrain Notes
docs.text:
• Max gradient 30° — Not scary steep, but pitchy enough to be fun
  • Trees are well-spaced — Great for snowboards (no tight squeeze)
  • Small creeks/gullies — Pay attention, especially in low snow
  • Canal near base — Easy to spot and avoid
  • Cross-country tracks at base — If anyone's feeling XC vibes

docs.title: What Makes This Special
docs.text:
• Town-run operation — No corporate vibe, pure local ski hill
  • Powder persistence — Because it's so unknown, fresh tracks last ALL DAY
  • Sunny aspect + low elevation — Perfect for cold days (which are common in Dohoku in Feb)
  • Training ground for Olympians — Yuka Takeuchi (Sochi 2014 silver medalist) trained here!

docs.title: DON'T MISS
docs.text:
• Single chair tree zones (both sides) — The real reason you're here
  • Ungroomed red courses — Powder playgrounds
  • Top-to-bottom runs (~1km) — Short but sweet

docs.title: SKIPPABLE
docs.text:

docs.title: RECOVERY RUNS
